model.hed: Best Hotels and Resorts in Tanzania: 2012
model.dek: Hotels and resorts in Tanzania on Cond√© Nast Traveler's 2012 Gold List: The World's Best Places to Stay

items.name: Lake Manyara Tree Lodge, Tanzania
items.description: Set in a forest of mahogany trees, these spacious stilted treehouses are "romantic and remote, with elephants walking around them." Accommodations have contemporary furnishings and are decorated in warm tones. One past guest was thankful for the indoor bathtub, as "the outdoor shower we were looking forward to using was infested with bees." An open kitchen allows guests to see their pan-African meals being prepared; "amazing service" means breakfast on a table by the flamingo-ringed lakeshore. Giraffes and cheetahs roam the woodlands and lakeshore.

items.name: Emerson Spice
items.description: Fusing a restored nineteenth-century Swahili sultan‚Äôs palace and Zanzibar‚Äôs first photographic studio, this multi-storied small hotel has an inner courtyard, six unique antiques-filled rooms, and one of Zanzibar‚Äôs best restaurants. Romantic, with blue-, pink-, and violet-painted walls, rich textiles, deep baths, and high beds.

fields.caption:
Fusing a restored nineteenth-century Swahili sultan‚Äôs palace and Zanzibar‚Äôs first photographic studio, this multi-storied small hotel has an inner courtyard, six unique antiques-filled rooms, and one of Zanzibar‚Äôs best restaurants. Romantic, with blue-, pink-, and violet-painted walls, rich textiles, deep baths, and high beds.





[read more](/hotels/africa-middle-east/tanzania/emerson-spice-stone-town-zanzibar-tanzania)

items.name: Kilimanjaro Hotel Kempinski
items.description: A renovated 180-room hotel across the street from the Indian Ocean, the Kili, as locals call it, is a modernist beauty that dates to the mid-sixties, when the newly independent country was full of optimism. Socialist economic fumbling followed, and the property eventually shut down for a decade. Happily, Kempinski has given the Kili a strong sense of place, with a stone facade, rooms that use the same bright colors you‚Äôll find in the local markets, and amenities including satellite TV and a big pool. The first-rate Asian restaurant instantly became the hottest table in town, and whether you need tickets on a flight to Zanzibar or want to climb Mount Kilimanjaro, the concierge is fast and reliable.

items.name: Kilindi Zanzibar
items.description: Not since the last sultan‚Äôs palace has there been anything so stylish on this fabled east African isle. The designers have created a landscape of whitewashed domes and arches that seem to mushroom up organically from the forested folds of Zanzibar‚Äôs north shore. Kilindi is generous with space: Fifteen pavilions are set on 52 lush acres with 1,640 feet of beachfront. Each hideaway is a maze of split levels and staircases latticed by a waterfall and two plunge pools. The breezy rooms are cooled by the trade winds (instead of air-conditioning), and the decor is uncluttered: handwoven baskets, a few seashells, and the odd cotton kikoy throw. By night, the scene softens with storm lanterns lit by hotel staff, who also patrol the premises. The hitch is the beach, which is used primarily by local fishermen and thus can be pungent. Better to laze by the T-shaped infinity pool and watch the dhows sail out while sipping top-notch cocktails from a bar that‚Äôs easily one of the best on the Swahili coast. The kitchen serves up yellowfin sashimi, octopus masala, and just about anything you fancy: When I found a plump mango that had fallen off a tree, the chef chopped it into my crab salad.

items.name: andBeyond Ngorongoro Crater Lodge
items.description: Located on the edge of the Ngorongoro Crater, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, this property has three camps and private butler service. Rooms have Victorian furniture, Persian rugs, and incredible Crater views. Expect pan-African cuisine in the domed dining room.

items.name: Ngorongoro Serena Safari Lodge
items.description: Clinging to the rim of Ngorongoro Crater, this visually-stunning resort was built from local river stones covered in thick vines. Every room has its own private balcony with sweeping views. Game drives, nature walks, and nightly Masai dances leave little to be desired for a luxurious safari experience.

items.name: Serena Mountain Village, Arusha
items.description: Built on the site of a colonial coffee plantation at the foot of Mount Meru, this hotel is "interestingly designed." Stone cottages are clustered in sixes, mimicking a traditional rondavel (African village), around flower-filled squares, facing Lake Duluti or landscaped gardens. "Rooms are excellent, but the beds are hard," though they are softened by linen sheets. Public areas reflect the hallmarks of an English farmhouse, with furnishings upholstered in floral fabrics. Anticipate spotting game such as buffalo, elephants, zebras, giraffes, and monkeys. Lamp-lit bush dinners focus on meat and fish.

items.name: Kirawira Serena Camp
items.description: Located between the crocodile-rich Mbalageti and Grumeti rivers, this Edwardian-style camp on a hillside puts guests in log-tethered stone-and-thatch accommodations with steamer-trunk wardrobes and brass lamps. In addition to game drives, activities include guided nature hikes, crocodile safaris, and excursions to Lake Victoria.

items.name: Gibb's Farm
items.description: Gibb‚Äôs Farm, with its colonial farmhouse on the wooded slopes of the Ngorongoro Crater, was built as a coffee plantation in 1929. Looking out onto the Great Rift Valley, accommodations in clustered cottages have wooden floors, wraparound windows, fireplaces, and bathrooms with indoor and outdoor showers. After bird watching, hiking or mountain bike trips, enjoy a classic English meal prepared with organic vegetables, fruits, and meats from the farm.

items.name: Lamai Serengeti
items.description: A luxury lodge with 12 chalets on a boulder-strewn hilltop‚Äîa prime location for observing the annual wildebeest migration. Four-bed chalets are suitable for families with children. California in the Serengeti‚Äîa bar furnished with tractor seats, a central lounge with plush white couches and African artifacts.

items.name: Lukula Selous
items.description: Safari lodges have been locked in an amenities arms race of increasingly tricked-out SUVs and villas citadeled in a mess of marble bathrooms and infinity pools. With just four (luxury) tents in a 300,000-acre protected wildlife reserve, the Lukula Selous is an ambitious new camp that harks back to the original Swahili meaning of the word safari: journey. Instead of passively watching animals from a jeep, you‚Äôll jump out to track them on foot, hiding in grassy outcrops to photograph elephants and hippos swimming in the river. Overnight portered safaris and fly-camping get you even closer to the rhythms of the reserve with mesh tents that allow you to fall asleep under a blanket of stars and awake with the first pink rays of sunrise. The main camp sits in the shade of a riverine forest on the banks of the Luwego River, and the sizable tents were designed based on nineteenth-century British explorer‚Äôs style, with elegant campaign furniture constructed from reclaimed hardwoods, flickering antique hurricane lamps, and handsome Egyptian rugs. Solar panels harnessing energy for the camp top shaded daybeds on stilts in the river. Even more important, the project is creating a model for sustainable tourism in Tanzania by converting an area that would otherwise be used for big game hunting, protecting the diversity that makes this one of Africa‚Äôs last great untouched wilderness areas.

items.name: Sanctuary Swala Camp
items.description: A hauntingly beautiful landscape of winding rivers, ancient woodlands, swamps, and open savanna, Tarangire is home to all of the Big Five except rhino and, although plagued with biting tsetse flies, is one of the best places in Africa to observe elephants and lions. Here, Swala camp‚Äînewly swank after an update and relocated amid a stand of umbrella-shaped acacia tortilis trees‚Äîhas 12 large tents on wooden platforms. All have private verandas, separate dressing areas, netted beds, and both indoor and outdoor showers; Wi-Fi is available in the reception area. You‚Äôll eat excellent modern African cuisine in the thatched open-air dining area that sits beneath a centuries-old baobab overlooking the water hole, which during the dry season attracts so many animals‚Äîincluding lions‚Äîthat you may be tempted to skip the twice-daily game drives in the tsetse fly‚Äìvulnerable open vehicles.

items.name: Sayari Camp
items.description: The northern Serengeti is the stage for the annual drama of migrating wildebeest herds crossing the crocodile-infested Mara River. Sayari, currently the region‚Äôs only permanent tented camp, delivers a degree of luxury unmatched by seasonal mobile safaris, including a large swimming pool, bar, library, lounge, and two tented dining areas atop a hill with views onto the Lamai Wedge, where the enormous herds gather. Each of the 15 suites has a tented roof, hardwood floors, and a private terrace; sliding-glass doors keep out insects and optimize views during the day, while zippered screens let in breezes and bush noises (howling hyenas and grunting hippos) but not mosquitoes at night. A resident spa therapist is on call for in-room treatments. Articulate guides display keen tracking skills on walking safaris and drives in open-air vehicles, and staff are happy to arrange alfresco candlelit dinners for couples seeking privacy.

items.name: Singita Grumeti Reserves
items.description: Singita Grumeti is comprised of four permanent properties and one mobile camp ‚Äì Singita Sasakwa Lodge, Singita Sabora Tented Camp, Singita Faru Faru Lodge, Singita Serengeti House and Singita Explore ‚Äì all set within 350,000 acres of land adjoining Serengeti National Park.  Sasakwa Lodge, the most sumptuous, comprises nine cottages suites and one villa styled as colonial manor houses, with fireplaces, antique bath tubs, a wraparound veranda, a plunge pool, and Wi-Fi. Between game drives, guests can smoke complimentary cigars at the main lodge‚Äôs bar, take tea in the garden sunroom, shoot billiards on a nineteenth-century table, and make free satellite phone calls; other diversions include an archery range and a stable of horses for gallops alongside the herds. On an open plain, Sabora has nine tents furnished with antiques from an English lord‚Äôs East African campaign in a 1920s style. Faru Faru‚Äôs eight tents sit in wooded country by the Grumeti River. A return to the very essence of safari, Singita Explore is a private camp that moves according to where the best game viewing is within the Grumeti Reserves and provides access to the most remote and beautiful locations. Singita Serengeti House, is an exclusive-use retreat designed to welcome friends and families to a relaxed home away from home. Up to eight guests can stay at Serengeti House and they can choose between the two suites in the main house or the two garden suites situated on either side.

items.name: Serengeti Serena Safari Lodge
items.description: Perched on a ridge with views over the savanna, this lodge exudes traditional African architecture with grass-thatch huts that resemble the rondavel dwellings of a Masai village. Accommodations are charming with natural stone bathrooms and private balconies. Located in Serengeti National Park, guests can see the annual wildebeest migration or the Big Five.

items.name: Singita Mara River Tented Camp, Serengeti National Park
items.description: Six luxurious tents, a pool, and a dining lounge on the Mara River, a location that enables guests to observe the annual wildebeest migration without leaving camp.

items.name: Residence Zanzibar
items.description: Sixty-six villas scattered over an 80-acre compound. All have butler service and plunge pools; some open directly onto a mile-long white sand beach flanked by coconut palms. A simplified blend of styles‚ÄîSwahili, Omani, Indian, British colonial‚Äîreflecting the island‚Äôs mix of influences. The minimalist rooms have huge mosquito-netted beds and freestanding egg-shaped tubs.
